Exercise

Using differentiation, find the Maclaurin expansion of \((1-x)^{-3}\).

(Hint : \(\dfrac{1}{1-x}=1+x+x^2+\cdots\qquad |x|<1\))

generalfeedback.text: Now, by differentiation, obtain the expansion of \(\dfrac{1}{(1-x)^2}\): \[\begin{aligned} \dfrac{1}{(1-x)^2}=\dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\left(\dfrac{1}{1-x}\right) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\left(1+x+x^2+\cdots\right), \\ &= 1+2x+3x^2+4x^3 \end{aligned}\] Differentiate again to obtain the expansion of \((1-x)^{-3}\): \[\begin{aligned} \dfrac{1}{(1-x)^3}=\dfrac{1}{2}\dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\left(\dfrac{1}{(1-x)^2}\right) &= \dfrac{1}{2}\left[2+6x+12x^2+20x^3+\cdots\right], \\ &= 1+3x+6x^2+10x^3+\cdots \end{aligned}\]
